39448688.review:
Here is what you do:
You play as the ghost of a person who was just killed on a boat. You are greeted by a kid who can talk to the dead who is able to tell you some basic information about where you are. You then have to go around the boat, possessing people as a means of interviewing everyone on board to find out who the murderer is.

What I like:
All the characters have a different personality and background. As you interview them you may be surprised by their individual histories and motivations for the future. The concept of possessing others to get them to talk to each other is interesting. Each character also has their own unique ability like peeking through doorknobs or reading people's emotions, but not all character abilities are useful to solving the case. There are several possible endings based on how much information you collect and your ability to conclude who the guilty party is at the end.

What I don't like:
I will admit this is a personal dislike, but this game contains some strong language. If you don't like the f-bomb, avoid this game. An NPC did get stuck on a corner in one of my playthroughs, and it was before I could possess him, so he was stuck there until I progressed the story meaning I couldn't complete a specific conversation involving him. I suspect this game could be buggy if you tried to find them. 

You can learn more in my video review:
https://youtu.be/A0YBGBHKdQ4

39347305.review:
[h1]"No matter how close you get to someone, you can never really know them completely".[/h1]

Я купила "Why Am I Dead At Sea" на распродаже, поведясь на приятную пиксельную графику, неприлично низкую цену в 50 рублей и хорошие отзывы. Каждый раз натыкаясь на неё в библиотеке, я твердила себе "когда-нибудь, может быть". И вот, это "когда-нибудь" наступило, и я осознала, как же сильно я недооценивала эту игру.

Вы оказываетесь на корабле посреди моря. Вы - призрак, маленький, едва теплящийся сгусток энергии, такой слабый и растерянный. "Кто я? Как меня зовут? Сколько мне лет? Что произошло? Меня убили? И если да, то кто?" - именно эти вопросы и удерживают вас в мире живых. Времени на разгадку так мало, а подозреваемых так много...

Кстати о подозреваемых. На борту корабля "Douce Amere" ни много, ни мало -10 человек: персонал и простые пассажиры. Поначалу персонажи кажутся картонными и сухими: тут вам и добродушный дедуля, и заводила-диджей, и молчаливая красавица, и адвокат в депрессии... Однако, чем дальше мы углубляемся в сюжет, тем больше понимаем: это не "клише-персонажи", и у каждого есть свои скелеты в шкафу. 

Открыто взаимодействовать с героями мы не можем (оно и понятно - мы же привидение). Нам под силу лишь читать мысли и вселяться в персонажей, чтобы говорить от их имени. Чем лучше мы узнаём персонажа - его прошлое, пристрастия, характер - тем больше вопросов мы можем задать. Звучит сухо, но на деле это очень занятная механика: все пассажиры взаимодействуют друг с другом по-разному, и если один от вас отмахнётся, то другой с радостью выложит всё, что знает. За это я и люблю видеоигры - они предоставляют новые способы повествования.

Собственно, к этому и сводится вся игра: к диалогам. Мы выслушиваем героев, пытаемся уловить в их словах правду, а иногда - даже помогаем им советом. К счастью, диалоги здесь прописаны отлично. Персонажам хочется верить,  им сопереживаешь, искренне смеёшься над их шутками. С момента моего прохождения прошли месяцы, а я всё ещё помню имена всех пассажиров.

Я мало в своей жизни читала детективов. Может, поэтому концовка игры стала для меня полной неожиданностью, хотя предпосылки, как оказалось, всё это время лежали на поверхности. В какой-то момент сюжет даёт крутой поворот, и все детали соединяются воедино. Концовок здесь 4, и, по традиции, есть "хорошие" и есть "плохие". Всё зависит от того, как тщательно вы расспрашивали пассажиров на протяжении круиза.

В общем и целом, я рекомендую вам попробовать "Why Am I Dead At Sea". Заварите чай, устройтесь поудобнее и отправляйтесь в плавание: "Douce Amere" уже ждёт вас у причала.

39267627.review:
“Почему я посреди моря? Почему я мертв? Где я? Кто я? Кто все эти люди?”
 
Такие вопросы приходится задавать себе безымянному, бесформенному сгустку эктоплазмы, который движется в неизвестном направлении на борту убогого круизного судна. Удачно подвернувшийся мальчик-экстрасенс объясняет, что совсем недавно здесь произошло убийство. Наше убийство. И есть основания полагать, что это только начало. Десяток потенциальных жертв заперты вместе с хладнокровным преступником на утлой, ржавой посудине посреди морской пустыни. Им некуда бежать. А нам нечего больше делать, кроме как пытаться им помочь. 

Странное дело, но “призрачный детектив” – это почти устоявшийся жанр. Возможно, таким образом легче побудить игрока к действию. Чужое убийство – личное дело потерпевшего. Если же прикончили тебя самого, волей-неволей приходится закатывать рукава. Но разработчиков, скорее всего, привлекают экстравагантные методы, которые могут себе позволить паранормальные сыщики.

Вот и на сей раз мы не ползаем на коленках в поисках доказательств. Вместо этого мы контролируем персонажа, контролирующего других персонажей. Вселяемся в людей и заставляем их самих искать против себя улики. Если подозреваемый что-то скрывает, надо стать этим подозреваемым, отпереть его каюту, накопать компромат, а потом предъявить ему находки, вселившись в другого бедолагу.

Круизное корыто “Douce Amere” укомплектовано жестокими, эгоистичными, глупыми, а порой и откровенно жалкими персонажами. Детективный сюжет любит снова и снова подрывать нашу веру в людей. Однако, герои вызывают не только презрение или негодование, но и сочувствие. У старых грехов длинные тени, а от человеческой натуры ничего хорошего ждать не приходится. Но у всех внутри с переменным успехом идет борьба света и тени.

Здешняя растровая графика не блещет яркими красками и эффектами. Она, напротив, аутентично воспроизводит атмосферу подержанности, бедности и безвкусицы. Корабль кажется достаточно старым, чтобы иметь два-три потайных хода между переборками. Достаточно дешевым, чтобы привлекать публику худшего пошиба. И достаточно гнилым, чтобы с первого взгляда вызывать самые острые подозрения. 

Тон повествования традиционен для бульварного детектива. Сухой сардонический юмор обрамляет тяжелую, мрачную историю. Пассажиры и члены экипажа не прочь пофилософствовать о природе добра и зла, преступления и наказания, жизни и смерти. Впрочем, без нравоучений и фанатизма. Личные трагедии не расставлены по кораблю отдельными экспонатами. Они так или иначе вливаются в общую канву. Все лгут. Все боятся. Все преследуют свои интересы. Поэтому мертвому следователю приходится работать на пол ставки психологом.
 
Праздная болтовня – дело грешное, но именно в ней скрыт ключ к правде. Да и ложь может рассказать не меньше, если вы умеете слушать. По сути, вся игра – один большой, завуалированный допрос. И чтобы не задавить нас лавиной информации, сюжет делится на условные главы, у которых есть только один диалоговый вход и выход. Таким образом свобода действий уживается с линейностью. 

Первая глава полна детского энтузиазма и такого же наивного неведения. Игрока наполняет ощущение вседозволенности. При этом нас невидимой рукой ведут по очень узкому сюжетному коридору, объясняя правила игры.
Вторая глава приносит понимание жестких ограничений и неизбежную фрустрацию, а так же детальное, въедливое изучае своего окружения и возможностей.
В третьей игра раскрывается во всей красе. Мы последовательно закрепляем свои успехи. Обстоятельства и причины преступления обретают очертания. Нас охватывает охотничий азарт… И, конечно, кончается все это внезапным и шокирующим поворотом, который разрушает ложное чувство контроля и безопасности. 

Оправившись от шока, мы начинаем складывать разрозненные детали в общую картину и, в конце концов, приходим к разгадке преступления. Или не приходим. Потому что “Почему я мертв посреди моря?” – это вопрос, на который никто за нас не будет давать ответ. И в этой автономности заключены как весомые достоинства, так и серьезные проблемы.

Скажем, один из персонажей стережет шкаф, который мы хотим обыскать. Мы вселяемся в этого персонажа, уводим в другую часть корабля, летим обратно, пытаемся открыть шкаф, но не можем этого сделать, потому что… в сценарии нет такого варианта. Подобные недоразумения убеждают игрока, что он гораздо умнее игры.

Но в итоге, когда все подозреваемые собираются в одной комнате и готовятся выслушать финальную разоблачительную речь, игра отыгрывается сполна, заставляя горе-детективов рвать на себе волосы. Представьте, что вы готовите блюдо по сложному рецепту. Каждый ингредиент должен быть заранее заготовлен и использован в точное время надлежащим образом. Одна ошибка, и блюдо безнадежно испорчено. Чтобы получить лучшую концовку, игрок должен найти абсолютно все улики, выпытать у пассажиров все тайны, а потом представить их в строгой последовательности, устами разных персонажей.

Но представите себе и другую ситуацию – вы пришли на экзамен, зазубрив ответы наизусть. Однако, экзаменатор хочет услышать от вас не только сам материал, но и его анализ. Эта игра доходчиво объясняет, что хороший детектив не просто копит факты, но активно с ними работает. Логика игры далеко не идеальна. Но автор всегда последователен в своих сюжетных и дизайнерских решениях.
 
“Почему я мертв посреди моря?” – это закономерный, интригующий вопрос. Много раз на протяжении игры я прокручивал у себя в голове имена персонажей, сравнивал их истории, пытался уличить каждого во лжи. А в самом конце, когда ответы на все вопросы уже давно лежали под самым моим носом, до меня наконец дошло, кто же все-таки меня прикончил. Ради подобных озарений стоит читать детективы. И играть в них тоже.

36639630.review:
Wow - I was skeptical at first but this game was so damn good. It's basically a murder/mystery RPG with a great story told in an inventive way that let's you gradually piece together the plot in layers as well as from various perspectives. The way it's implemented embellishes an already well-written story and keeps your attention the entire time. 

You wake up as a ghost without any knowledge of yourself, and need to figure out who you are as well as who on the cruise ship murdered you. You work towards these goals by possessing the suspects (crew and passengers) to take control over their bodies and investigate them. While possessing someone, you open up new dialog possibilties with other characters - and also gain a special skill that's unique to each character such as being able to peek in door keyholes or read people's emotional state. You can only possess people after learning personal/private details about them so you need to find ways to accomplish that during the investigation since it's critical to progressing the story. There's also two different levels of possession which makes things even more interesting by adding another dimension to the concept. Between the dialog choices from all possessed suspects' story threads and special skills, you come to understand/experience the plot in additive layers of detail from different perspectives. I really enjoyed playing multiple storylines and watching how they weave together while collectively manipulating the suspects through  forced interaction with possession. It comes together seamlessly as such a unique experience.

I can't believe this game is only $5. I played through it in about 7 hours or so and there's still a few more endings to see. I really enjoyed the graphics and the music was awesome too. Overall the entire game felt well polished in every way. The only complaints that I had, which didn't bother me at all really, are: a) can only have one save file which can be annoying with multiple endings, and b) collision detection between characters at times was a bit sticky.

36456611.review:
Great Game - 9/10

This is largely a game about exploring motivations, relationships and personalities of the weird passengers on this "cruise ship". You are trying to solve your own murder but in order to gain access to people and information you spend a lot of time getting to know the staff and passengers. Everyone has a story and most people have secrets to reveal.

Pros - Gripping story, great characters you learn a lot about, interesting premise and mechanics, awesome soundtrack, lots of twists

Cons - You'll find yourself going over the same dialog trees way too often, You will have most of the ship explored before the first chapter is over, Some of the mystery is a bit obvious if you pay attention (especially when you read people's minds).

C'était très bien !
On joue donc un fantôme "amnésique" et bloqué sur un bateau en mer. Il faudra découvrir des choses sur les passages/membres d'équipage pour pouvoir les posséder et pousser son enquête plus loin pour découvrir de nouvelles choses et, [I]in fine[/I], qui était notre personnage et comment est-il mort.
J'étais assez intrigué par le mécanisme de "possession" et s'il faut bien dire que le gameplay n'est pas ultra-riche (on sent quand même bien qu'on est sur des rails et qu'il faudra dérouler tel ou tel dialogue pour passer à la suite ; mais un jeu "d'enquête" où on a l'impression d'enquêter librement, est-ce que ça existe vraiment?), j'ai pris beaucoup de plaisir à révéler toutes les histoires des différents personnages qui sont assez variées et bien écrites je trouve. La BO est vraiment bonne et influe vraiment sur l'ambiance que dégage le jeu. J'ai particulièrement apprécié [SPOILER]les tableaux "abstraits" lorsqu'on est sous forme de fantôme et qu'on lit dans les pensées d'un personnage[/SPOILER].

34505749.review:
感觉在已经有一篇足够详尽的长评的情况下我完全不需要写这篇评测……但就当是到此一游了吧。
推荐。鉴于国区价格不高，加上这游戏鲜少打折（夏促都没打），感兴趣的可以直接原价拿下。

整体来说，这个游戏的气氛偏向于灰色。不知身份的“你”死在了船上，又被寻求帮助的少年拉了起来，开始调查你的死因，以及船上潜藏的秘密……差不多就是这样。不会写简介，非常抱歉（鞠躬）

+剧情不错
+角色刻画的相当好，大家都是有故事的人
+对于一个以剧情为主的游戏没啥多的可说了
+在文本量的支撑下，细节比较丰富
+补一句吧，附身的设定做的挺好的（相对前作增补了若干内容），对话的时候根据你的附身方式，可以看到不同角色之间基于各自立场的互动，也可以以“你”的视角直接发问。

-跑路有点多。因为排列组合的原因（每两个人间的对话都是不同的），游戏流程虽然不长却有着海量的对话，虽然理论上每一段对话都可以帮助玩家了解剧情和角色，但是对于急于看完主线又有强迫症的玩家，很容易就烦了。（遇到这种情况请看攻略（自吹自擂））
-有两个角色的结局没有交代……虽然可以做出合理脑补，但脑补终究是脑补啊。

最后，温馨提示：
·还有没看的对话的角色头顶上是有气泡的，所以就不用费心思再去一个个找头顶没气泡的人了

33823468.review:
Why Am I Dead At Sea is a "background discovery" game as I'm calling it in this review, the game's premise is that you're on a boat, having a cruise, but, there's a catch, you've been murdered.
You play as a wisp, who can talk to this kid name Paulo, and you can possess many characters, with varying secrets, backstories, and charicterastics, varying your playthrough. You use this mechanic to find out who murdered you, how, and why. This mechanic is handled very well, actually, as like this : say, you possess Person (A), and talk to Person (B), about something like what they ate for dinner, and then possessed Person (B), and talked to Person (A) about what they had for dinner, you would know, because you previously communicated before, but, If you then leave Person (B)'s body, and possess Person (C)'s body, and talk to Person (A), about what they had for dinner, you would not know, unless you found out, because you learnt that in Person (A)'s/Person (B)'s body, meaning you would have to find it out again, if you have the option to.
The mystery solving is very intriguing and you have continious questing for "Who did it?" and your bond with characters build up, and up, you could be controlling your murderer, or not, who knows? who, if anyone, told them to do it?
The puzzle solving is very good, but annoying at times, and you may have to check a walkthrough at some times, but it is inevitably pleasing when you complete a hard to beat puzzle.

Great game for a cheap price, many endings to change things up a little.

33783636.review:
[h1] Wow. [/h1]
I did not expect that.
This might be one of the best indie games I have ever played.
In this game, you are a ghost trying to piece together your own murder case.
You do so by taking over the passengers and talking to each other.
Getting a whim of their personalities allows you to follow them around (you control their movement, but you can't relay information that you know through them).
After getting to know them intimately, you can finally possess them and speak through their mouths, relaying that information that you've pieced together through other characters and exploring the ship.
This game throws a lot of twists into the story. Some bigger, some smaller.
Some fairly predictable.
It keeps you interested throughout. It's a game that you can't really put down until you finish it.
Something that I really enjoyed was the Mindreading mechanic.
It doesn't really advance the plot (which is sad, cause that would've been kinda cool), but god is it aesthetic. 
The cat one is probably my favourite.
This game features multiple endings based on the evidence that you collect throughout your journey.
I recommend not looking at guides on how to get them until you finished the game once (don't worry, you can't really miss evidence until the very end. If you save, you can collect the rest of it before entering the finale).
Sometimes it can get kind of frustrating, in which case, look at a guide or keep trying.
The soundtrack is very memorable since its mostly tied to the characters. This gives every track a personal feel to it and it also helps giving life to the characters themselves. The melodies reflect their personalities.
The graphics have a very earthbound feel to them. They're fantastic for a pixel-art game.
The longer you play, the more do you get a feel for the ship, It's rooms, the character's usual hideouts.
One gripe I have with this game is that every character has his/her own special ability.
They really do range from kinda-, no - sorta-, nah, maybe important? to completely useless. 
For example, one character's ability is to see what other people have in their pockets.
Yeah. It's never used.
It's kinda sad actually. It could've been used for some cool evidence collecting.
Like, what if you look into someone's pocket and you find the protagonist's handkerchief in there?
Then you could point it out and they'd get all nervous, which could then later be used as evidence.
That's just an example. Not sure how you make the "take pills which make you run faster but also muddle up the screen" ability useful in collecting evidence. It just feels like a tacked on feature, which is sad. It could've been a pretty cool mechanic to be honest.
I've encountered one bug where Donnovan wouldn't meet me in his room and I'd be locked out. If that happens to you, just talk to him again and wait until he goes back to his room.
Now I'll get into spoilers, DON'T GO PAST HERE IF YOU HAVEN'T FINISHED THE GAME.
THE GAME IS FAIRLY CHEAP AND QUITE AN AMAZING JOURNEY.
SERIOUSLY, BUY IT.
PLAY IT.
PAST HERE IS NO-NO ZONE.




okay? good.

Aber die Story ist wirklich erste Sahne und absolut mitreißend. Wir spielen einen Geist an Bord eines Schiffes. Dadurch ist der Spielraum natürlich begrenzt wie ein klassisches Kammerspiel, hat aber natürlich den Vorteil, dass man sich nach relativ kurzer Zeit sehr gut zurecht findet. Nach und nach lernen wir die Passagiere und Besatzungsmitglieder kennen und können sie mehr oder weniger manipulieren, um zu verstehen, was an Bord vor sich geht. (Jede der manipulierten Personen hat außerdem eine besondere Fähigkeit, die uns mehr oder weniger nutzen kann.) Irgendwas scheint hier nicht mit rechten Dingen zuzugehen. Wer sind wir eigentlich? 33000167.review:
Why Am I Dead At Sea takes a simple concept (of what is essentially a point and click adventure minus clicking) and alters many core elements to make the game stand out among others in its genre. However, these were core elements for good reason, and the changes cause problems that are uncommon and jarring for the genre. But whatever the verdict, it's a unique ride all the way. 

The main draw to Why Am I Dead At Sea is its story. Without spoiling it, the basic premise is that the protagonist is a ghost (assumedly recently dead) trying to sort out, well, why it's dead at sea. This transforms the narrative into a murder mystery with a twist, as you can posses and manipulate the various characters during their own investigations. I personally love this mechanic. Instead of using a pointer, you'll control the ghost with a controller or in my case the keyboard. This makes the game significantly more interesting, since each character has a different ability, so once you unlock a new character you'll be able to explore the ship more efficiently (at least in most cases). Overall, this mechanic is the best part of the game. It makes playing the game more interesting than clicking and scrolling through text, it works well with the setting and tone of the game, and it combines some of the better parts of a first person and omniscent perspective without any narrative hiccups.

Speaking of the narrative, it does it's job well for a story rich game. The game is paced well, and has a great climax that will lead to one of the multiple endings. As far as the actual writing goes, you can learn a lot (I'd say a little too much) about characters and the mystery simply by reading the dialogue (which takes up most of the game). The characters are diverse, likable, and relatable, and the dialogue is well written. There are also a few missables that answer some questions that the main story never does.  And to top it all off, most of the characters' simple designs work with the visual style without seeming too basic. After all of this, it sounds like a perfect game, but unfortunately this isn't the case. 

My first problem in the game is that many of the mechanics are buggy. It's surprisingly easy to get stuck on a single pixel or clip through a wall, and since the game has manual saving, this can lead to loss of progress. I'd advise avoiding walls when you can ([spoiler]and not abusing the cats jumping ability[/spoiler]). To be fair, I only experienced issues twice in my two full playthroughs, but as both instances led to lost progress, I resent both of them.  

Secondly the narrative progression has some small issues due to the game mechanics. In most adventure games you'll expect a certain ammount of trial and error, but this game makes it much worse. Because each character is different, certain actions will only cause progression if done with a specific character. There is a speech bubble that will appear over a characters head when they have something to say to whoever you're controlling, but because you can only control characters one at a time (and the NPCs won't stay put while unpossesed), you may have to check each character, with every other character multiple times in order to progress. There is one chapter in which you must talk to one character with three different characters in order to progress to the next chapter. For this reason, I found myself possessing characters en masse and trapping them all in the observation room so I could check for new dialogue without having to walk back and forth between rooms. And what I discovered by using this strategy during my second playthrough was easily the most disappointing part of the game.

Now, the following contains pretty blunt spoilers. It does not contain any details that would spoil the plot, but this information will likely ruin the climax and any multiple playthroughs for you. In my case, ignorance was bliss, so I'd recommend skipping this part if you haven't played the game yet. However if you do intend to 100% the game, the following information is important.   [spoiler]Simply put, the different endings, aren't. There are two good endings, two bad endings, and the best ending. The good endings are nigh identical, the bad endings [b]are[/b] identical, and the best ending seems like a watered down combination of the good endings. Every ending answers all of the main games questions, so the only thing different about an ending will be parts of its dialogue. Furthermore, only the actions you take in the penultimate chapter affect the ending, although the game seems less linear than it actually is. With a guide (and no spoiler guides do exist) it is possible to play the game up to a point in the next to last chapter, save, and experience every ending from there by slightly altering your actions (which is how my second playthrough went). The multiple endings are easily the worst part of the game, as they encourage multiple playthroughs in a game that's best on the first play. The only rewards for reading through the same dialogue multiple times (i.e, 100% completion) are the achievements.[/spoiler] 

If you've made it to the end of this review, I'd simply like to specify that I do think Why Am I Dead At Sea is a good game. If you like this kind of game you'll definitely enjoy it, and if you don't it will likely change your mind. But in my case, I feel like I went in too deep (again) and ruined what was a fun experience for me by overthinking and overplaying it. If you're just looking for something new to play, I'd say go for it. If you intend 100% the game, or follow in my footsteps, approach with caution and reasonable expectations.

If you're a fan of murder mysteries, supernatural themes, or like character driven games with lots of text, I highly recommend this game. Heck, even if you're not a huge fan of those things I still would probably recommend this game! In Why Am I Dead At Sea, you explore a strange cruise ship as a murdered soul, learning bits about the passengers and crew members and piecing together the mysteries behind them, your murder, and the ship itself. I enjoyed possessing people and searching the ship, trying to find new info that would help move the narrative along, but if you're not into a lot of walking and talking that might get old quick. There are a lot of secrets in this game however, many of which are tied to the original flash game Why Am I Dead (which isn't necessary to play before this game), and I liked searching the ship for all of the achievements.
 
My only warnings about this game besides what I mentioned above would be some of the themes and potential glitches in this game. Despite it’s fairly harmless appearance, Why Am I Dead At Sea has heavy themes and language that might surprise you if you’re not prepared, so if that isn’t your cup of tea, consider yourself warned. I have also seen complaints of glitches around, but I never experienced any during my own playthrough.
 
If any of the above has piqued your interest, Why Am I Dead At Sea is definitely worth the price, especially if you buy it on sale. I believe a game with the thought, story, and soul of Why Am I Dead At Sea is easily worth 5 bucks!

31812981.review:
I buy alot of cheap games here on steam. Most of the time they've got little good pieces but are overall pretty bad. But every now and again, I find a real gem hidden in all that dross, and this was one of them. Low production value, a number of minor non-gamebreaking bugs, but superb mystery and characters. Honestly, I found that this game captured all the things I liked about the Nonary Games (albeit in a different format and without escape sequences.)

The game takes the form of an overhead RPGmaker style game (without combat), like corpse-party or mad-father. You play as a ghost who can possess characters to some degree and read minds, but not work outside the context of that character's norm. A few characters have special abilities (technically they all do, but most of them are abilities like 'i change the background music' or 'I made amusing and silly flavor-text announcements over the PA' or 'I take a pill to walk faster'). So that means most of the game is instigating conversations between different people, although there are a few "figure out how to get the key" moments. In any case, swapping characters is a great mechanism for allowing you to investigate the story from different angles. As you get to know certain characters better, you get higher degrees of control over them, and so in some situations you need to learn more about each character to advance the plot. 

There is a hint system as well, although it was disabled at the end of the game when I really needed it. It offers both vague suggestions that give you a rough idea of where to look, but you can press for more specific ones. I did the specific one once, and the result was almost as explicit as a walkthrough "try taking this character and talking to this other character to open up more dialog options, then return with a different character and they'll react differently." I liked that because it ensured you never got really stuck, but again, it is disabled at the end and I ended up getting stuck once, although I did feel like the specific ones were a bit too easy.

This game is a murder mystery, and an excellent one at that. Multiple people are working in different directions, without knowing the entire story. Everyone has their secrets, and almost noone is who they initially appear to be. It creates a complex and intricate situation to unravel. The game does an excellent job of dropping just the right hints and the right pieces to keep things interesting without giving away too much. 

The ending takes place with a big confrontation between all the characters, a little like you'd expect from an Agatha Christie novel. Except instead of a detective putting together all the pieces of the mystery, that role falls to the player. So you take control of each character to get them to reveal their piece of the puzzle, and try to reveal the whole mystery. I'll admit, I missed a few pieces the first time, so the game ended with parts of the mystery unsolved. I'm not sure how many endings there are, but apparently there's more than one. I need to go through a second time to see if I can figure out the rest of it. 

The character development is one of the best things about this game. There are numerous characters, all with their own backstory and motives. Some are innocent. Some, not so much. Everyone's hiding something though, and as you sort through the evidence you come to understand the characters and get attached to them in their own way. Their interactions are complex and dynamic. Manipulative and dishonest at times as well (at least if I didn't misinterpret any pieces of the mystery)

There are lots of problems with the game too. The character sprites are good, but everything else is kind of bland. The music is simplistic and obnoxious, and I ended up turning off the sound about a half hour after I started the game each time. The characters were said to each have special abilities, but I'd say maybe half at least of them were useless. Also, the story can get caught at times, and your only way to continue is cycle through each of the characters and they've all talked to each other and exhausted all dialog options, which is a pain. The scenery never changes either. There's maybe two dozen rooms, most of which are tiny, and they get kinda old by the end. 

Also there are alot of bugs... nothing game-breaking, but just annoyance kind of stuff. The biggest one I saw was when you tried to enter a room, but another character was blocking the door in the other room. You'd enter and get pushed back out, or end up inside a wall. Also, sometimes you'd click on a door and it wouldn't react at all. Normally you'd get a "door's locked" or "I shouldn't go in" message, but sometimes you got nothing. There was an ability for the ghost to scan who he could control, and it lagged horribly whenever I used it. Also the game wanted to restart every time I exited it, so I could only close it by rapidly jamming alt-f4. Nothing gamebreaking, but obnoxious. 

Overall, I would highly recommend this game. If you like mysteries with strong characters anyway. It's got alot of little bad things, but the overall game is so great. The game took me about 7 hours on my first playthough, although may have left it idling a few times while I got dinner ready, and I'm not sure how much that inflated it. Still, it's much more length than I usually get out of a cheap game like this. The characters and mystery were masterfully executed.

I will certainly keep an eye on this developer. If they can produce more stories with such great characters and plotlines, especially if they can add a little more polish, we might be looking at some real masterpieces in the future.

31784090.review:
I love this game. The name, honestly is pretty dull and the art is barebones but what makes up for all of this is an excellent murder mystery wrapped up in flawed and interesting characters.

One of my favorite choices design-wise is a character named Paulo. He's completely isolated from all the action and therefore I never felt pressure when talking to him. Paulo gives a little backstory but what I especially loved what that he exists as essentially an in-game walkthrough. Paulo will rarely give straight answers, but he will point you to what characters/ areas of the game you need to focus on to complete the story. He's a great crutch for players (like me), who frequently struggle to solve these types of games but he doesn't take the fun out of solving the mystery. He does what Contradiction's chief tried to do, but he fills his role much better because of how we are introduced to Lewis. Such a simple character that gives the player a lot of leeway in how they want to approach the game!

Another thing i liked: i got the feeling the game had a lot of respect for the player. There's a point in chapter two where one of the main riddles of the game could have been solved with context clues in the dialog, but the answer is never spoken out loud until chapter three. However, at the end of chapter two the game gives dialog options to the player as if the mystery had already been revealed. This showed me the game had faith that the player was working the mystery on their own and didn't need obvious plot points to be outlined to them.

Noteworthy: The game gets dark, but it's not really edgy like a lot of games are now. This is a personal thing, but I hate games that try to be edgy, pushing things sexual harassment and gruesome murders in the gameplay and forcing the player to watch. Not that the game strays from those topics, but i appreciated the tact shown when handling sensitive subjects. 

There are a ton of choices in the game, but never does the player have an actual impact on the story. While you can approach the story in a nonlinear fashion by following different leads and characters, the narrative is ultimately linear and events happen in a fixed sequence. I appreciate this, because it meant for things like dialog are almost always repeatable. This is a very pleasant change for someone whose always worried about missing an option, even if it's a little disorientating when you give conflicting answers to one question.

Now with all that said, I did have several issues (mostly technical) that would have made me quit the average title. These include:
-having to completely restart my game because the first mate got stuck inside an invisible wall. Easily the biggest issue
-Almost all the controls for gameplay are with keyboard, but in the audio menu you can only escape using the mouse?
-the name, while descriptive, is pretty dull. If it wasn't on sale I’d never look into this game.
-unskippable cutscenes
-there is no auto-eject out of conversations. Honestly this one is super nitpicky, but i hate accidently starting conversations and having to mash through 4 textboxes
+-to that point there is also no button to progress a conversation other than 'k,' or whatever you remap it to. This means if you mash 'k' too fast you can accidently conversation you might accidently start it again. Having another button to progress the conversation that doesn't start a new one would be nice.
-sometimes crewmen back block doors. I see no reason why collision with other passengers is needed, especially with this sort of drawback
-The ending feels really messy. SPOILERS: The best ending comes out in a clever and logical way, but it's attachment to 4 other endings makes it an extremely painful trial and error bonanza (if you don't give up and grab the walkthrough like i did). Moreover, the entire game is designed so that you can also go back and redo events, and nothing you can do is permanent. Having major elements of the story locked away behind optional activities at the very end feels cheap as hell, mostly because it only happens once in the entire game. Considering the games linearity up the that point, it might have made more sense to have only one or two endings. 

All that icky stuff aside, love the game and will definitely be looking for other stuff the dev has made :D

31758157.review: What an amazing game. The music is great and I love how every character has a track that describes them. I like the mechanics of how you gain partial and full control of characters and how you need to be thorough in interrogating them all to uncover pieces of the truth. Don't know what else to say, it's just a really charming game.

You do this by posessing the passangers and crewmembers, lightly setting them into the good direction but they are making their reactions based on their personality. 30973855.review:
This game is absolutely worth your time if you like ghosts, murder mysteries, or story-driven games, and it's a steal even at the regular price. It's a bit on the shorter side, but the multiple endings, engrossing story, and rich details make it worth at least one replay. 

This isn't the only game where you play a murder victim back from the dead (with Ghost Trick being another great example), but Why Am I Dead At Sea executes the concept masterfully. The mechanics change as the player gains a better understanding of their former identity and the people around them, tying together narrative and gameplay in a way that feels satisfying and natural. All the characters have multiple layers, and their interactions are realistic and well-written. Also, I loved the way the human mind was handled. Reading someone's mind displays some abstract visuals that give you a glimpse of their general attitude, with snippets of text floating by as their surface thoughts. It's not a huge deal, but it does a great job of making the mind feel dynamic and real. Much more creative than just having a line or two of inner monologue. Also, interaction between characters is well-written and engaging, even in cutscenes when the player isn't at the wheel. For the most part, the things a posessed character is willing to say will tell you as much as the answer you get in return. Also, even within the same ending, characters will act a bit differently depending on what you made them say earlier in the game. Otherwise, the story is mostly linear before a certain point, although some things don't need to be done in a certain order. This gives the player a nice sense of flexibility.

There were a couple of issues I had, though. First of all, the last stretch of the game is a bit difficult to navigate. The pacing of the story doesn't suffer much, but there's a relative lack of guidance and some of the things you need to do are accomplished in an unintuitive way. Throughout the game, it can be difficult to figure out what to do, but this issue becomes more pronounced as the game goes on. A more astute player might have less trouble juggling all the information they have, but sometimes it's hard to tell which character needs to talk to who, especially near the end. Also, while the endings are mostly satisfying, I felt like a couple of characters could use a little more focus, or at least acknowledgement. Those issues, in my opinion, are still far outweighed by the strength of the characters and the excitement of unraveling the story.

In conclusion, Why Am I Dead At Sea is a thrilling experience, packed to the brim with complex characters and unique mechanics. An excellent mystery and a great game.

Being able to possess characters with different skills to solve puzzles was immensly satisfying, and just challenging enough to avoid boredom or frustration. I highly recommend Why Am I Dead At Sea!

30645688.review:
The general concept of the game is already well presented, so let's just skip to the pros and cons:

Pros: 
- The characters are memorable.  They vary in depth, but most of them have multiple levels that make them interesting to discover.
- The story is above average.  There is a nice sense of progression -- although the fact that it will have twists is obvious, what those twists are isn't always.  

Neutral:
- The majority of the game is the conversational aspect.  There are very few puzzles, and what puzzles there are are pretty simple.

Cons:
- A game-breaking bug where characters can get stuck in place and unable to move, requiring you to edit the save file to continue.   You're advised to keep multiple saves.
- The plot runs on a script, regardless of your choices.  If you figure something out before you're supposed to, you can't do anything about it until the plot catches up.  Towards the end, you may know exactly what you need to do, but get stymied because you can't figure out the series of actions the game is expecting to advance the plot.
- The game begins to fall apart, mechanically, towards the end.  Actions that were able to be done earlier in the game cannot be repeated even though there's been no change, some actions (like attempting to open a locked door) no longer give any feedback at all, etc.
- Sometimes keystrokes are dropped, especially during conversations.  This is doubly annoying because you don't want to accidentally overpress the key either, or you'll inadvertently skip things.

All in all, I enjoyed the first 75% or so of the game, but the last quarter just got downright frustrating, which unfortunately left a bad aftertaste.  Still, I got several hours of enjoyment out of it, making it worth the $5 going price, much less the the $2 I actually paid for it, so it still ends up with a positive rating.

28981715.review:
All things considered, this is a good story. I say "story" rather than "game" because I think there's this notion going around that a video game has to have gameplay. This doesn't. You interact with the world and the characters through a set of mechanics, but it's more a storytelling device than a game.

There were things I didn't like. The supernatural angle didn't end up being particularly relevant. It only provided a way within the context of the story for the player to interact with the world. I'd have like to see it taken further. There are a couple of optional scenes in which the player character uses their ghostly powers to help a character conquer their personal demons from within. I wanted to see more of that, but then the game ended.

If you've played Capcom's [i]Ghost Trick[/i] - and you should - I'd compare this game to it as shorter, less interesting, with a less satisfying ending. But it is more grounded, which can be seen as a good thing, depending on whether you think the supernatural element clashes or not.

All that said, if you ever have an urge for a murder mystery thriller story with a supernatural framing device, this game is what you're looking for.

26858418.review:
[quote]Верите ли вы в справедливость этого мира?[/quote]

Как думаете, сколько людей ежегодно умирают в море? Это покажется невероятным, но по исследованиям около 372.000 человек. "Вот это да", - скажете вы и представите в голове всех этих людей, тонущих одновременно. Не самая радужная смерть, конечно.
Так вот. В данной игре мы играем за призрака, в прошлом он был... кое-кем, кто тоже умер в море. Но вот как он умер? Утонул? Повесился у себя в каюте? Поскользнулся на верхней палубе и упал за борт прямиком в пасть акулы? Кто знает... Хотя, по первым мелькающим кадрам, становится понятно, что это[spoiler] убийство.[/spoiler]Вот и думай теперь, как ты умер, да почему. Вот таким недостатком информации игра потчует нас с самых первых минут. Мы играем за призрака, который находится на корабле. Ему необходимо расследовать причину своей смерти, а также попутно узнать информацию о себе и о прочих пассажирах корабля. Ведь не просто же так мы вернулись в этот мир.

Выглядит игра в изометрическом стиле, с очень уютной, прямо "по-домашнему" симпатичной пиксельной графикой. Да, это инди-проект, но любители ААА, не спешите с выводами. Музыка в принципе неплохая, пара-тройка треков даже может остаться у вас в голове, чтобы когда-нибудь вы вернулись к этой игре. В звуках нет ничего особенного. "Пиканье" в стиле 90-х для "озвучивания" речи и набор не самых выдающихся звуков (но это не значит, что они плохи). 

На корабле у нас числится 11 человек (включая нас), кошка и... а это уже найдите в самой игре. Очень хотелось бы написать о каждом более подробно, но это тот самый случай, когда интересно всё узнавать самому. Скажу только, что каждый персонаж яркий и колоритный, со своим характером, очень запоминающийся, со своими тайнами. У игрока нет ни капли информации и он черпает её по крупинке. Но, кое-что для разогрева интриги знать всё-таки нужно: призрак имеет определённые способности. Вселяться в людей, управлять ими, читать их мысли. Подобное было в громком проекте от Square Enix - Murdered: Soul Suspect. Но здесь это всё в целом выполнено НА ПОРЯДОК лучше, поверьте моему честному объективному слову. Правда, приходится чем-то жертвовать, и игра проходится буквально за 4-5 часов. Но это даже не минус! 

В целом, это инди-жемчужина, но, к сожалению, малоизвестная. Как видно по оценкам Steam, у неё исключительно положительные отзывы. Несколько отрицательных связаны с какой-то технической проблемой, а не историей игры. Но игра была обновлена после тех обзоров и теперь она ещё стабильнее. Осмелюсь сказать, что по крутости она может потягаться с самой To the moon, вот только Мэдисон её не обозревал. Только другого жанра, это следует учитывать, чтобы меня потом просто так не закидали тапочками.

26207424.review:
[h1]Spoiler-free review[/h1]
I'm very critical when it comes to this type of indie game, but the writing in this one is actually very good. Perhaps most importantly for me, the dialogue writing feels fresh and interesting. The story keeps your curiosity piqued, and your brain working on figuring out the mystery. It's good stuff.

It gets off to a really good start that's almost immediately very engaging and dramatic (in no small part due to the soundtrack), and its characters feel surprisingly nuanced.

You get access to various unusual abilities that you can use while exploring or during conversations, and it meshes really well with the story (even if some are more useful than others. But I don't really see that as a flaw.)

Lots of things about this game work really well, but it does have a few pretty significant problems:

[b]Technical Issues[/b]
I've had to restart the game multiple times before I was able to finish it due to various technical problems, the most common of which is that some characters will get stuck before they reach their destination, and can never get unstuck.
Another odd issue i got was that the game's save files seemingly deleted themselves overnight.

[b]Design Flaws[/b]
It's very easy to get stuck not knowing what flag you haven't tripped so you can move on to the next thing. But the game dialogue is also oddly structured, which hurts the game's pacing.

Often, you seemingly need to "talk to everyone about everything", but the dialogue trees are oddly designed in that choices don't "stick". You can say every possible choice by just repeating a certain dialogue tree path.

If you haven't exhausted all your dialogue with a character, there's a "..." icon, but it doesn't go away before you've made every possible choice.
So the problem is the character you're controlling has to be a total weirdo who starts multiple identical conversations about the same topic by saying the exact same thing at first, and then ends it by, for example, stating wildly different opinions each time, say, 4 or 5 times, to the same character. This doesn't make sense in the narrative of the game, and stands out especially because the game is well written.

It seems to me that the game is signalling that exhausting all of these dialogue options and thus removing the "..." icon from every character is required to progress - but I'm honestly not sure how that really works. It's entirely unclear as you're playing, and becomes especially apparent if you (like me) end up playing the game multiple times.


[b]In conclusion[/b]
Skill and effort went into crafting this story, and I recommend this game to people who enjoy a good mystery.

If you can find a way to back-up your save files, then you might want to do that in case a character gets stuck, or the saves decide to disappear like mine. Or just beat it in one sitting.

I found it quite enjoyable despite having seen perhaps the worst of its flaws.

25414852.review:
[i]Why Am I Dead At Sea[/i] is a murder mystery adventure game where you play a ghost with the ability to possess each of her potential murderers and lead them to find clues against one another in order to figure out whoddunit. A great concept, excellent execution, fun world design that rewards exploration with insight, just a wonderful and memorable gaming experience.

I am so into these games that offer unique modes of storytelling, I mean, it's a brilliant solution to a concept I've always hated in games: dead-eyed, slack-jawed NPCs who sit around waiting for you to do every little thing. You're ostensibly playing one entity, but really this game has more in common with "split the party" type horror games like [i]Siren[/i] or [i]Corpse Party[/i] where you play different people caught in the vortex of one event, each with their own fully realized personalities and desires. The care that has been put into constructing the characters is really what makes the game so great. Each character has unique music that plays when possessing them, a unique mindscape that can be peeked into, a unique placement in the societal incubator that is the setting, and each has different methods of talking to the other characters and dealing with the world they're situated in. In order to possess them, the game asks that you understand them, and thus witness them through the eyes of the people around them and then ultimately through their own. 

What results is a game that feels very empathic, very alive, where both the player and the characters seem to have so much agency towards pushing the story forward and solving the mystery. This ties into the existential crises of nearly all the characters, which range from poverty to surviving the suicide of a loved one to facing their own imminent deaths, the game offers several discussions on time and moving forward, overcoming traumas and spending whatever time you are given meaningfully and not just keeping your head down and doing the bare minimum to achieve comfort.

And the mystery is good! And more importantly, it's something you can figure out with the clues you're given even before you get to the final judgement, though how to organize those clues into evidence is harder than it initially seems.

Now, I did face a little bugginess, but nothing game ruining. Also I would have liked everyone to have different colored text boxes or something, it gets confusing in group scenarios. Otherwise... its-a goooood.

24764062.review:
Such a neat little casual mystery game. As the title implies, this game's universe revolves around a journey at sea on what seems to be a particularly small cruise ship.

You - as the player - are handed control over a spirit. And that spirit is an energetic remnant of what was once a human being, who unfortunately died under strange circumstances.

The fun thing about controlling this spirit, is the ability to float through doors. And that inevitably means you get to take peeks behind closed doors... in spaces that hold secrets.

Yes... secrets. We're here to uncover secrets. One obvious secret revolving around the protagonist's demise.

But there's more... mhmm, a couple of subplots that tie in beautifully with the main plot.

So, on this ship there's a lot of moving from one cabin to another on different floors (which unfortunately has the process feeling repetitive and even dreadful at some point, but because the story takes place on a tiny cruise ship; it's kind of fun and doable, thanks to speedy movement of the spirit).

This spirit has no memory of what happened, where, when or how it occurred (which is very distressing & confusing to this little residual ball of energy), but of course we are here to do something about that, ey!

And the way this is done, is by first being informed of the spirit's death, thru a very young passenger on board (i.e. Paulo) who is capable of tapping into the paranormal (and thus, communicating with spirits).

His guidance jumpstarts the exploration process and makes it easier to grasp what's going on and what to do.

He explains the process of possession/mind control, and encourages you to test the process on a cat which happens to be in his cabine at that time. 

Concerning possession; the game logic goes as following; the most insecure passengers of the whole lot are to be possessed first - which is simply figured out thru trial-and-error -  and via them you get to know the stronger minded folks (and thus possess them afterwards).

The more you know about someone, the easier it becomes to manipulate them (i.e. their insecurities weaken their aura so-to-speak, and allows for easier 'entry' in their body).

There is a basic possession mode & a full possession mode.

In order to unlock 'full possession' (which in this game, equals the unlocking of specific dialogue lines - which are required in order to progress and find out what really happened - one has to become acquainted fully with all passengers on board.

And this is where a lot of running is done, because you're required to possess each and every one of them to get answers, progress and finish the game.

The one thing that really stuck with me (after finishing up) was the music and the graphics. And heck, even the plot. 

The plot was nice. It was good enough and it made sense.

A really cool thing they did in this game is the ability to see inside the passengers minds. 

What you get to see is a graphical representation of what their mind looks like (this is done thru clever use of colour, music and specific phrases, which reflect their thoughts & demeanor).

This really adds to the atmosphere of the game. 

Each character has their own theme music (which plays when they're possessed + in their cabins) and this really helps grasping their personalities.

On top of this, when the characters converse, their personality is emphasized thru sound & pace (as the dialogue appears on screen). 

So even though, there's no voice acting present, it IS possible to 'feel' what the characters are like, because of the smart application of sound & tempo in regard to dialogue.

How this works is; as the words appear on screen, sound is played for every letter that pops up.

I thought that was really awesome. It made a difference. This is a feature I had come across before in games (especially of the RPG type), and it simply works well for this game.

This is a game I would so replay if they ever decided to remake it in an upgraded version :).

24481487.review:
A fun, engaging, and well-thought mystery aboard a small ship. 

You're dead, and you don't know why, how, or even who you were/are. You're stuck on a cruise ship with a motley assortment of passengers and crew. Everyone is weird. Everyone is suspicious.

Luckily, you can partially possess people and move them around the ship to uncover clues about your death. When you control a fellow seafarer, you not only get to abuse the relationships they have with other people on board, but you get access to a unique skill that can help you move around or talk.

This was a real lucky find for me. I love games like this, especially when they have a "fishbowl" setting. Getting to know the passengers is easy and fun. Learning the truth behind the whole setup is rewarding.


PROS:

-Good story
-Well-writen
-Interesting characters
-Fun mechanics
-Creative ideas
-Easy to learn
-Quick intro (straight into the action)
-Multiple conclusions

CONS:

-Rough around the edges
-Semi-buggy (nothing broke for me)
-Some ideas were under-utilized (unique character actions, etc.)
-Characters at the beginning get neglected at the end
-Mediocre audio

I've seen this is a spiritual sequel, although I never played the first. The one real flaw in this game is that as you play it, something inside you knows it could be better. There's a lot of potential here, either in a completely re-polished version or just another sequel in the same vein. Still, I HAVE to recommend this. It's a fun way to tell a story and it shouldn't be passed up.


PLAYER SKILLS REQUIRED:

-Interest in reading
-Interest in mystery
-Tolerance of trial and error

24194362.review:
Just beat the game today, and have to say, I was pleasantly surprised. Like a lot of reviewers, I was immediately drawn to its Earthbound-style graphics, and expected a lighthearted indie romp through a ship. That compairson shatters within the first five minutes of gameplay, though. The 90's nostalgia and surreal charm of Earthbound are nowhwere to be found. Instead, you find yourself on a third-rate ship, among its cynical inhabitants. You've been murdered, and a telepathic boy named Pablo has pulled your soul back into the land of the living. He explains that in your current state, you can't open doors or speak to people, and must possess a living person to talk and search for clues.

And that's the basic premise of the game: possess people and puppeteer them into revealing conversations. The more conversations and clues you amass, the more leverage you have over the ship's occupants, and the more you understand about who you were and what's at stake. In general, it plays like a lot of early 90's point-and-click games, trying different dialogue combinations with different characters. Some might find that frustrating, but I honestly found it a highlight. I miss old games like that.  If you get too frustrated, though, Pablo offers hints throughout most of the game (usually two hints per section, a "where should I go" style hint, and a "complete this part for me" style one).  

Sadly, these hints fall away where they're needed most, in the fourth act of the game. Up until that point, there's a sort of internal logic that can point you in the right direction. By act four, though, your choices are too broad, and there's no rhyme or reason for the interaction combos you need to pick. After reading a walkthrough, I understood why the choices I made were necessary for the story, but still thought "I never would've realized that I should possess this character and speak to this character after doing this not-very-obvious thing." You lose sight of why characters are motivated to act the way they do, basically. 

That said, I still enjoyed the story quite a bit. It was a solid, unpredictable muder-mystery with a interesting game mechanic. The music never felt out of place, and a lot of thought given to the personality and backstory of each character, even down to how they speak to one person versus another. Overall, I'd recommend this to anyone that wants to hear a good story, even if the last parts can be a bit frustrating.

[spoiler] When you are finding out more about the characters, you might find out Darryl's backstory.  He was happily married for three years, until one day he came home from work late to find his wife had committed suicide by medication overdose.  She had anxiety issues, the extent of which he was not fully aware of, and so it came as a total shock.  If you read his mind and listen to his apathetic speech you'll see he is quite clearly depressed.  He carries empty pill bottles in one of his pockets, and his ability is to take a pill which increases his speed but also blurs his vision (and yours, by default). 22897020.review:
[b]“But what I mean is, lots of time you don't know what interests you most till you start talking about something that doesn't interest you most.” ― J.D. Salinger, [i]The Catcher in the Rye[/i][/b]

[i]Why Am I Dead At Sea[/i] is an underrated gem created by Peltast Software just a year ago. Aside being an incredibly well weaved murder/mystery, it is a unique game that presents the rare opportunity of taking a glimpse on the human nature and the perpetual failure to communicate with one another, keeping unintended secrets while failing to hide things that they intended to hide to begin with. Through associations of the language and the mind, we are to investigate a horrifying affair. You should remember that you can only discover what people do care about the most by taking note on what they do not care about.

Our story starts with a brutal murder; a soul is snatched away from its mortal body before its time. We start as the fragment of this soul, as a piece rendered out of personality due to shock and we remember not a thing about our former mortal identity. Who were we? What happened? Who killed us? With all these ominous questions at mind, we awaken. A young boy medium seemingly managed to help us manifest at the last minute, thus our scarred consciousness has taken form in the cruise ship he's been travelling in as a ghost. We are to wander around, listen to passengers and the crew, and influence their actions by possessing them in hopes of revealing the vile businesses going on in this ship to reach some kind of closure.

The game manages to present a unique atmosphere with a limited environment. We are in an old cruise ship with 3 floors: the residential floor for passengers, the residential floor for the crew and the deck, alongside utilities and recreational areas. Graphics-wise, it's nothing exceptional, but these limited areas are well used in both in display and story purposes, harboring countless unique details that you may investigate and discover. All characters have their own background music, dominating the game according to your interactions with them - and with your ability of taking a glimpse to their minds, you'll gather uneasy clues about their goals and pasts.

We are given unique gameplay dynamics and a well written story. All characters involved has complicated personalities, various conflicting motives and secrets to keep depending on their situations. With all parameters involved, [i]Why Am I Dead At Sea[/i] may be interpreted as an Agatha Christie novel with supernatural undertone. You are welcome to possess people if you are to grasp a basic understanding about their personalities and motives only - and still then you can only present subconscious suggestions to manipulate their actions. They cannot talk about a subject they have no idea about to begin with! For the full control of people, you should first reveal the fundamental drive that each of them possess. Only then, you can completely control their actions and speak through their mouths. Each character has a unique ability that could become useful in your investigation, including your ghost self. By revealing details of your own past and personality, you are to gradually gather your former self and memories, presenting grander abilities with stronger manifestations. As the story progresses, you'll find yourself in a web of intrigue, lies and misconceptions.

This whole experience takes 5 chapters to wrap up - 4 investigation chapters and one conclusion chapter - and contains 5 different endings according to your ability to conclude the interrelation of all happenings during the last chapter, presenting you genuine replayability. All said and done, [i]Why Am I Dead At Sea[/i] is a noteworthy experience and a thrilling story with more than decent narrative and personality depictions. Enjoy!

Please also check out Lady Storyteller's Curator page [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/ladystoryteller#curation]here[/url] - follow for regular updates on reviews for other games!

Aside from it's quirky pixel artwork style and chiptune soundtrack; I loved how you were able to travel as a "ghost" orb around the ship [spoiler] and over time became whole again.[/spoiler] It made me feel that someone had put a lot of thought into how to show progression in the story in terms of finding out who you were. The Characters are charming, interesting to learn about and I liked how deeply personal the Characters would become the further you progressed into the game. 

The game will keep you guessing who dunnit until the very end. Several times, I was so sure I had figured it out, only to be talking to another passenger and go "Wait, that contradicts what so-so said" or "WHAT. No. Are they implying what I think they are?" 

It's not a scary game as such, but some of the dialogue does catch you off guard and creates a sense of dread and eeriness to the gameplay. Some of the evidence/clues you find in game, don't appear to mean anything early on, but at the end it all clicks into place and shows you exactly what is implied. One noteable example of this is [spoiler] at the very end of the game, where their "ambiguous job" becomes clear. All through the game I thought nothing of it, until the end when I finally realised what it meant. Ugh...how could they boil it down to that like it was nothing? Ugh...[/spoiler]

For me it's a little bit difficult to heavily criticise the game but I did find one thing that i'd put as a con:  If a Character is standing in the path/blocking a door, you can't just move past them unless you are the "ghost". I found that a tad annoying that I had to wait for them to move, or posess them to move them. When I did this, sometimes the person I needed would run back to another floor and I had to chase after them to get them back! 

Overall, I'd definitely reccomend this if you want both a deep meaningful story and thought provoking mystery game with a slight twist.

22031156.review: The main mechanic is really cool. It's got a decent plot, great characters, and a solid soundtrack. I had a lot of fun playing it and getting all the endings. Probably a favorite, despite being short.

21954610.review: Truly an Earthbound-esque game! Unique and has a powerful story that just gets deeper and deeper. If you are new to mystery or want to find a unique take on it, this is your game!

21940148.review:
유람선 위에서 벌어진 살인 사건의 진상을 파악하라!

MOTHER 시리즈를 보는 듯한 도트 그래픽이 대단히 인상적이다. 보나마나 MOTHER 시리즈에 영향 강하게 받은 것이겠지. 캐릭터와 배경 생긴 것 뿐만 아니라 아예 대화창 까지도 그냥 MOTHER다, 이건. 이 그래픽 때문에 이 게임에 끌린 거긴 하다만.

육체를 잃어버린 영혼이 되어 이 사람 저 사람 몸 속을 돌아다니며 다른 등장인물들과의 대화를 통해 잊어버린 자신의 존재를 깨닫고 사건의 진상을 추리해나가는 게임이다. 자기가 조종하는 캐릭터를 바꿔가며 플레이한다는게 꽤나 재밌게 느껴진다. 그 밖에 캐릭터마다 특수능력을 하나씩 활용할 수 있는데, 게임의 진행상 꼭 필요한 스킬을 지닌 캐릭터가 있는가하면 도무지 왜 넣어놨나 싶을 정도로 방해만 되는 능력을 지닌 놈들도 있다.

영혼 상태에서는 이동 속도도 보다 빠르고 좀 더 자유롭게 다닐 수 있는 데다가 각 캐릭터들의 생각을 읽어낼 수도 있다. 각 캐릭터들의 생각이 굉장히 개성있는 비주얼로 표현이 된다. 개인적으로 이 게임에서 가장 높게 평가하는 부분. 

줄거리는 전형적인 추리극 스타일로 흘러간다. 사실 내용 자체가 아주아주 뻔하게 흘러가기 때문에 눈치가 조금 빠르다면 중반부에 이미 어느 놈이 수상하고 어느 놈이 범인일지가 금새 파악이 될 것이다. 멀티 엔딩이라 재미있을 것 같다만, 엔딩들을 전부 보고나면 이게 대체 서로 뭐가 다른건지 그다지 파악은 잘 안 된다.

사실 마더 시리즈 생각나는 그래픽이랑 사운드 빼고나면 쯔꾸르랑 그다지 다를 건 없다. 이 정도 수준의 게임이라면 알만툴로도 얼마든지 만들 수 있을 것 같다만, 그래도 등장인물의 생각을 들여다보는 그 연출 하나만큼은 나름 돋보였다.

21932231.review: Had a lot of fun playing this game. Well-crafted characters, awesome music, cute art, and an engaging story! The dialogue flows very nicely, especially for this genre; every character has their own unique voice and are interesting to interact with, as well as play as. Just have to get all the endings now!

21900388.review:
我咋就死海上了哩（Why Am I Dead At Sea）是我咋就死了哩（Why Am I Dead）及我咋就死了哩：活啦（Why Am I Dead: Rebirth）的续作，由这个系列是近几年我玩过的看上去最Earthbound的游戏，美术风格充满了这款传世大作的醍醐味……不，几乎可以说是完全一样了：sprite的画法丢进Earthbound去完全不会有任何违和感。

好啦这样的译名是开玩笑的……

上文提到的Why Am I Dead及Why Am I Dead: Rebirth都是flash游戏，在kongregate可以免费玩：
[url=http://www.kongregate.com/games/peltast/why-am-i-dead]Why Am I Dead[/url]
[url=http://www.kongregate.com/games/peltast/why-am-i-dead-rebirth]Why Am I Dead: Rebirth[/url]
如果对这款小游戏有兴趣的话，可以直接玩rebirth，基本上相当于前者的重制版。

Why Am I Dead At Sea于去年二月通过绿光并于五月正式发售，让我惋惜的是这样一款游戏并没有获得足够的关注。它的风格、玩法与故事有足够的潜力让它成为一批人心目中的独立游戏佳作，很可惜这样的事情并没有发生，在我写这篇评测的时候它也在Steam上也仅有55篇评测，metacritics上甚至没有任何用户评分。但是你一定要问我，WAIDAS滋磁不滋磁，这游戏评价这么少玩家不滋磁它呀？他是个独立好游戏，我们怎么不滋磁独立好游戏（？）

——————————————————
由于正文结构有点乱，我先给个TL;DR版：

优点：
+有新意的玩法
+不错的剧情和角色塑造
+画面非常Earthbound，sprite清新好看
+BGM在气氛烘托上效果很到位

缺点：
-流程短
-系统上有累赘设计
-叙事上有些许漏洞
-少量bug

Verdict：推荐
——————————————————

言归正传，如同商店页面的介绍，故事是这样开始的：

[b]你在一艘船上，
而且死了。[/b]

与前作的困在风暴中的旅馆相同，这也是典型的与外界隔绝的凶案现场。经典而老套的悬疑故事设定，迫使主角在事态进一步恶化前解决事件。不同之处在于你是死者的……死魂灵（？），这点在设定上与Ghost Trick及Murdered: Soul Suspect相似，但封闭的设定使游戏的篇幅更加简短。这样短小的故事带来的好处是更加可控的故事及发展，因此作者也能大胆给玩家多那么一点自由度，反正整个场景就那么点，人物就那么几个，加上章节式的结构，随你胡来也不会糟到哪去啦……

游戏的目的是找到真相，进行的方式是附身。主角可以附身在其他乘员身上，通过他们的视角，引导他们说出该说的话来调查与交流来推动剧情发展，找回记忆，并将真相的碎片拼凑在一起。你可以观察他们的内心，就是商店页面中那些够意识流的画面没错——这个能力从功能性上而言基本鸡肋，即使你推动了剧情，或者与其他角色有了足够多够重要的互动，内容也不会变，你也无法从中得到任何足以推进故事的线索，但……这毕竟是一个了解lore的能力。当你对一名角色的了解足够深的时候，你可以完全占据他/她的身体，通过他们说出主角想说的话。

从玩法上来说是挺有新意的，但有些系统有些累赘。我感觉dev在做头两章的时候思路还没有定下来，他们希望比起Why Am I Dead能够添加新的功能和系统，但没有仔细考虑这些东西该怎么用。比如第一章里你可以控制角色像Earthbound那样带着队友到处跑，但这样的场景再也没有发生过。然后之前说的那个看别人内心世界的功能实在也挺鸡肋……再比如我在前面都不愿意提起的扫描能力，你可以看到哪些门你的灵魂能够进去哪些进不去，哪些人能占据之类的……完全不知道这有啥用啊？！目前我发现的这个能力唯一的用途[spoiler]就是发现一个场景中的另一个幽灵[/spoiler]了……

虽然你控制了一名角色，但他/她会说出来的话是受到她的性格和知识限制。每个角色关注的话题不同，比如Alton就会想要大家去他负责的Observation Room玩，而Sue则更关心每个人的工资水平，诸如此类。而当你完全占据了一名角色的时候，你就可以用过他们的嘴以你的知识说出你真正想说的话，但有些特定的对话也只有特定的角色对其他角色说才会触发，而这正很好地服务于……

角色塑造。不同的角色也拥有不同的能力，他们的能力与角色的性格与设定基本相符，因此也导致了一些鬼用没有的能力……但换一个角度看，若将能力视为角色塑造的一部分话，就挺合适的了。Why Am I Dead At Sea这款游戏最成功的一点就在于角色塑造：简单而直指人心的对话，加上角色脑内活动以及平时的活动，将一群有血有肉的鲜活的人展现在你面前。每个人，如同我们，都具有私密的欲望与阴影，差异鲜明的性格与爱好，这个短小精悍（大约5h上下能打通一轮）的游戏居然能将角色塑造得如此之好，挺不得了的，也可能只是我移情作用太强了……

剧情的进展是章节式的，随着剧情推进最终你会到第五章的解谜篇，总体来说这个游戏处处都有经典到成了cliche的组织结构呢……

在解谜篇中，你在之前的章节中获得的信息和证据（以及部分和个别角色的互动）会决定结局的走向。一共有五个结局，导向不同结局的选择则在于你在最后的standoff中在什么时机下用什么角色提供了什么信息。而因为有的信息所有的角色都不知道，因此有的路线要求你完全占据某人，说出你的幽灵知识，走向grand finale。如果你在这之前错过了一些信息，有的结局你就走不通了……

总体而言，Why Am I Dead At Sea的剧情比较令人满意，美中不足的是有少许情节上的漏洞[spoiler]，最后对主角的交代不够，以及部分结局中对一名角色完全没有交待[/spoiler]，以及虽然有五个结局，但结局后的过场只有两种。此外，对话中有许多选择支不会造成任何影响并且可以重复对话，还是蛮可惜的。比如我问你滋磁不滋磁，你可以回答滋磁，然后再对话一次回答不滋磁，也是完全没有影响的。

另外游戏还有一些小问题：

1. 一些trigger的设置问题导致了在一些角色被附身时，即使他/她缺乏一些信息，仍能与一些角色触发关于那些信息的关键对话。
2. 有少量图像显示问题，这一点在Observation Room最为明显。
3. BGM的播放和循环有些问题，会导致在一些时候完全没有音乐，而有时则同时有两个BGM同时播放。

音乐还算不错，有几个曲子在一些场合烘托气氛效果很好。但总体而言曲目数过少，但想想游戏也就这么点规模也倒算是够用了。OST在bandcamp可以免费下载（支付0美元）：
[url]https://billkiley.bandcamp.com/album/why-am-i-dead-at-sea-ost[/url]

21880629.review:
Why Am I Dead at Sea is an adventure mystery game, wherein you play the role of a ghost who has no recollection of who they are, how they died, or why they were killed. Throughout the game, you are set upon the task of finding out the answer to each of these enigmas, and in doing so you will also learn much about the passengers and crew aboard the ship. I've been waiting almost a year to finally play this title, so needless to say I was hoping that I wouldn't be disappointed; I definitely got a lot more than I expected out of this experience.

The game plays out like an incredibly gripping novel, and at any point it's overwhelmingly difficult to put it dow for even the briefest moment. You will want to continue playing through until the end, so that you can unravel the questions that were roused from the beginning. You will initially start off by getting to casually know the people aboard the vessel, but as you progress throughout the four chapters you will get to know their most intimate details and innermost thoughts. The character building, and the relationships that are formed between them, are key points to the success of Why Am I Dead at Sea; many of the details that you will learn later on in the game, and especially what lies in wait at the end, will have many players on the Feels train, headed full speed towards Feelsville.

So as you may be able to determine, the title relies heavily on dialogue. That being said, the actual gameplay is minimal; as a ghost, you are able to possess the other people on the ship, as well as use their unique special abilities. These special abilities range from extremely beneficial, such as Donnovan who can highlight interactive objects, to utterly useless, like Darryl who can walk faster but at the disadvantage of having the screen become disoriented. Needless to say, you probably will not utilize of most of these special abilities, despite possessing the characters multiple times. To fully understand the story, and to uncover your "true" self as the ghost, you will talk to everyone around the ship at least once on every chapter, and at some point you will also be tasked to investigate every room aboard the liner. These are not incredibly daunting or time consuming tasks, as the boat only has three floors and ten passengers.

Once you get to know a character completely, you are then free to fully possess them; doing so enables new dialogue options to appear at certain stages of the game. Once you reach the end of the fourth and final chapter, you then proceed on to unlock an array of different endings. While the endings are somewhat diversified, there is in fact one true ending in the mix; however, you are still left to piece together, yourself, many of the riddles that the game presents. This is a nice change of pace, versus games that feel the need to explain their outcome in excruciating detail; it also leaves an air of mystery to the title, and one that is open to interpretation.

As a final note, I will say that the soundtrack by Bill Kiley is an absolute masterpiece. I never found myself getting tired of the amazing retro, Sega Genesis styled bytes that were infiltrating my ears; from the downright creepy, to the dubstep influenced, to the upbeat. The only gripe that I do have is that each letter of dialogue makes a sound, and it overtakes the background tracks. These sounds, however, can be easily bypassed by pressing the action key; although it would be nice to have the option to turn it off completely. It's also worth noting that if you enjoy retro soundtracks, the one for this game can be downloaded for free, or pay what you want, at Bill's Bandcamp page.

Why Am I Dead at Sea is one of the best mystery games on Steam at this point, and it's unfortunate that it's severely underrated and often bypassed. As of now, this will be the 55th review for this game. The depth of the characters is really where this game shines, without that element, Why Am I Dead at Sea would not be the diamond in the rough that it is. The only way that the experience could've been improved was if the ship was a little larger, and the story a little longer. With talking to everyone, obtaining all of the endings, and earning all of the achievements, I clocked in at a little under 5 hours. Since the time that I initially posted this review, this title has seen a significant price drop, and the current price of $5.49 CAD is very fair for the amount of content that you get. If you can nab it on sale, it's one hell of a steal for a must-play title.
